newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Justice Dept. allows Microsoft to buy WebTV.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Justice Dept. allows Microsoft to buy WebTV.

text.p: The Justice Department said Friday it approved Microsoft Corp.'s proposed $425 million acquisition of WebTV Networks Inc., which offers Internet access using televisions.

After what it described as a "thorough investigation," the department said it had closed the probe into whether the acquisition would violate antitrust laws and decided not to challenge the deal, which was announced in April.
Microsoft said it completed the deal late on Friday.

"The investigation confirmed that a number of other companies, several of whom are significant participants in the computer or consumer electronics industries, have or will soon enter the market with competitive products and alternative technologies," the department said in a brief statement.
The department in May requested additional information about the deal after a number of Microsoft's competitors complained it could lessen competition.

WebTV designs the specifications for TV set-top boxes and built-in television connections that allow for accessing the Internet. It offers Internet service through agreements with service providers that supply connections around the nation.

Steve Perlman, WebTV's chief executive officer, said this week that he expects to reach 250,000 subscribers by the end of the year, more than double the current number of users. The Palo Alto, Calif.-based firm has nearly 400 employees.

Opponents of the deal charged that WebTV represented another way to access the World Wide Web, along with the personal computer brower software already sold by Microsoft. They argued the deal would increase Microsoft's ability to dominate access to the Web.
The department over the years has conducted a number of investigations involving Microsoft and still has underway a long-running antitrust investigation of Microsoft's Internet software business.
The department sued to block Microsoft's proposed acquisition of Intuit Inc. for $2.3 billion in 1995, a deal the software giant later abandoned.
In 1994, the department negotiated a consent decree that set restrictions on Microsoft's practices in the market for computer operating systems.
